title: Apple Watch
summary: The Apple watch came out in 2015.

title: Chrome
summary: The Chrome internet browser came out in 2008. It is developed by Google and has become the most popular internet browser today. Since its release, the use of Internet Explorer has plummetted down to about 11% while Chrome usage has increased up to 63%.

title: iPhone
summary: The Apple iPhone came out in 2007.

title: YouTube
summary: YouTube.com was created in 2005 as a video sharing site and in 2006 it was acquired by Google. YouTube is changing entertainment, communication, and advertising in society. Popular YouTube channels get enough revenue through advertising, that many people are now creating YouTube videos for their income and becoming a YouTuber as their profession. Some YouTubers are even making millions of dollars annually through ad revenue.

title: Arduino
summary: The Arduino was created in 2005 by Massimo Banzi, a software architect and professor, as well as several others. At the time, Banzi had to use the BASIC Stamp microcontroller with his students, but the BASIC Stamp was not powerful enough and was too expensive. This led to the development of the Arduino microcontroller which costs less and is easier to use. The Arduino now sells for about $30, and is used by hobbyists and students.

title: Opteron – first processor to support AMD64
Wi Fi
summary: In 1998, the Netscape browser source code was released, and the Mozilla project was started in the community to create a better browser. In 2002, when the majority of people were using Internet Explorer, the Mozilla browser was released, and in 2004, Firefox 1.0 was released. This was the first big competitor for Internet Explorer.

title: Mozilla Project
summary: In 1998, the Netscape browser source code was released, and the Mozilla project was started in the community to create a better browser. In 2002, when the majority of people were using Internet Explorer, the Mozilla browser was released, and in 2004, Firefox 1.0 was released. This was the first big competitor for Internet Explorer.

title: Google
summary: In 1997, Google.com became a registered domain name, and in 1998 Google became a company. Google.com is now the top search engine in the world, with about 90% of people using Google over other search engines. The Google search engine has become so popular that the use of the word "Google" as a verb is widely used to describe searching the internet. The company Google is even concerned about trademark rights to the word "Google". Since then, Google has become a leader in technology and innovation, expanding beyond search engines by creating Chrome, Google Maps, self driving cars, and more.

title: HTML and the Web
summary: In 1989 at CERN laboratory, Tim Berners-Lee invented the Web and HTML, and in 1990, his web browser was released on the NeXT computer. Hypertext markup language was based on standard generalized markup language, or SGML. Many of the same tags used in SGML were used in HTML; however, HTML also included hypertext links with HREF attributes. The invention of the Web and HTML has completely changed society. As of early 2015, over 3 billion people used the internet.

title: First Dot-Com Domain
summary: The first dot-com domain, symbolics.com, was registered in 1985.

title: Windows
summary: Microsoft released Windows in 1985 as a competitor to Apple's graphical user interface. Originally Windows was just a GUI that ran on top of MS-DOS. It evolved into the most widely used operating system today. In 2015, Windows was used on about 90% of PCs.

title: Apple's Lisa
summary: In 1978, Apple started the Lisa project, and in 1983 Apple released the first personal computer with a graphical user interface. At the same time Apple was working on Lisa, they also started the Macintosh project. The Lisa had more advanced features which were later integrated into the Macintosh as well.

title: First IBM PC
summary: IBM was known for building massive machines that required full air conditioned rooms and a staff to maintain the computers. In 1981, IBM's first personal computer was built using existing, tested hardware and operating systems from other vendors. This strategy allowed them to create a product in only 12 months. The IBM PC allowed users at home to use word processors, play games, and more.

title: WordStar
summary: In 1979, WordStar was released as one of the first word processors. Word processing has helped to change communication and collaboration, especially in education. People could type up documents with typewriters; however, modifying documents was difficult. With the introduction of word processing, people could easily share, modify, and revise documents. This helped teachers as well as students work more efficiently.

title: VisiCalc
summary: VisiCalc is a spreadsheet application that was developed for the Apple II. It was widely used by businesses and schools, becoming a killer app that drove the sales of Apple II.

title: Apple II
summary: After the Apple I’s success, the Apple II was developed a year later to be mass produced for personal computing.

title: Apple I
summary: The first Apple computer was sold in 1976. They were originally hand built by Steve Wozniak. Other computer boards at the time had to be put together. Although the Apple I still needed a case and power supply, the board was completely assembled.

title: UNIX
summary: AT&T’s Bell Laboratories developed the UNIX operating system and distributed it for free, leading to many different versions. Both Linux and Apple’s OSX are UNIX-based operating systems. The development of UNIX also led to the foundation of how computers determine time. The UNIX epoch is January 1st, 1970, and all computers now determine time by the number of seconds passed since this date.

title: Integrated Circuit
summary: In 1958, two people separately came up with the idea for creating integrated circuits on a single chip. These people were Jack Kilby at Texas Instruments and Robert Noyce working at the Fairchild Semiconductor company. The invention of integrated circuits made it possible to make smaller and cheaper computer components.
